In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This technical assistance (TA)1 will respond to a request by the Government of Bhutan 
for additional support from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to strengthen its external audit 
institution,  the  Royal  Audit  Authority  (RAA).  The  TA  for  Strengthening  Audit  Resource 
Management will build on ongoing ADB TA to improve public financial management in Bhutan 
and expand the RAA’s capacity. The new TA is included in the Bhutan country operations 
business plan (2011–2013).2 An ADB consultation mission visited Bhutan in September 2010 to 
discuss the details of the TA with the RAA. This resulted in agreement on the objectives, scope, 
approach,  financing  plan,  and  implementation  arrangements.  A  fact-finding  mission  in 
November 2010 reviewed and agreed on the design and monitoring framework and the terms of 
reference for consultants. 
 
2.  The  TA  supports  the  emphasis  in  Bhutan’s  Tenth  Five-Year  Plan  (2008–2013)  on 
building transparency and accountability in the country’s institutions. The plan makes good 
governance a key development goal and the government sees the strengthening of the RAA 
and other accountability agencies as crucial to this strategy. The third pillar of the ADB country 
partnership strategy (CPS) for Bhutan is good governance.3 Rapid growth in Bhutan’s economy, 
the expansion of government expenditures that has resulted, and the government’s continuing 
fiscal  decentralization  all  require  that  the  RAA  become  better  able  to  ensure  that  the 
government’s performance complies with its accountability criteria.   
 
3.  ADB’s ongoing TA has been improving audit resource management at the RAA.4 The 
new TA will augment this effort by helping the RAA acquire and put information technology (IT) 
systems to work to raise operational efficiency and improve in-house training. This strategic IT 
intervention will seek to  meet important needs in Bhutan for better governance and more 
accountability in government operations. Rapid growth combined with an aggressive pursuit of 
democratization and decentralization has widened an existing audit gap much faster than the 
RAA is able to fill it. The requested TA aims to address this key issue and help ensure that 
Bhutan continues its steady progress toward its developmental goals.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Bhutan’s economic growth during the past decade has been unprecedented. Its gross 
national income per capita increased from $730 in 2000 to $1,900 in 2008. The incidence of 
poverty declined from 36.3% in 2000 to 23.2% in 2007 and the country is on track to reduce this 
rate to 15% by 2012–2013 under its Tenth Five-Year Plan (2008–2013). These are remarkable 
accomplishments by a country that was among the least developed in the world until 20 years 
ago. Notably, economic progress has been achieved amid continuing political stability and a full 
opening of democratic space. Growth and change have not come without the usual challenges 
to good governance and sustainable economic development, however. 
  
5.  The government has been at the forefront of the country’s development and its activities 
and  expenditures  have  increased  sharply  along  with  expansion  in  the  economy  and  the 
transformation of Bhutan’s society and institutions. Seeking to ensure that growth reduces 
poverty and brings equitable socioeconomic development, the current five-year plan’s emphasis

on good governance includes the goal of proper management and the best use of public 
resources to ensure administrative and financial efficiency, transparency, and accountability, 
and  to  improve  public  service  management  and  combat  the  spread  of  corruption.5 The 
government made the RAA a constitutional body in 2005 to pursue these goals and established 
an  anticorruption  commission,  It  considers  the    strengthening  of  both  institutions  highly 
necessary (footnote 5, p. 62) and believes this strengthening  requires the development of 
appropriate and effective IT and communications systems (footnote 5, p. 62). 
 
6.  The TA will seek to improve the RAA’s ability to execute its mandate under the Audit Act 
of 2006 and to fulfill its enhanced  role under the Public Finance Act of 2007.6  The new 
constitution adopted in 2008 directs the RAA “to audit and report on the economy, efficiency, 
and  effectiveness  in the  use  of  public  resources.”7 The  constitutional  requirement that the 
central  government  ensure  sufficient  intergovernmental  transfers  to  the  dzongkhags  (local 
government districts) for them to operate in a decentralized setting heightens the demands on 
the RAA due to the greater fiduciary risks inherent in fiscal decentralization. Decentralization is 
meant to improve service delivery and accountability but it may initially increase the danger that 
public resources will be wasted due to (i) growth in the number of civil servants with cashier 
functions and thus more opportunities for misappropriation of funds, and (ii) a decline in the 
quality of public expenditure management because of the limited skills of local officers.  
 
7.  The RAA faces these difficult tasks even as it broadens its audit focus beyond financial 
audits to applying compliance and performance audits across a bureaucracy that is growing and 
becoming more complex. It is also seeking to build its capacity to apply internationally accepted 
standards of audit, a goal reinforced by in its membership in the International Organization of 
Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI). The RAA’s request for additional ADB assistance to 
establish IT innovations in its audit operations cycle and, by doing so, to rapidly equip its staff 
with necessary tools, reflects its recognition of the need for it to scale up quickly to meet these 
challenges.8 ADB’s  earlier TA  conducted  a feasibility  study  of  commercially  available  audit 
management software for the RAA but the cost of the system it recommended substantially 
exceeded the TA budget for IT procurement (footnote 4).  
 
8.  The RAA conducted due diligence on the recommended software and concluded that 
many of its functions were not relevant to its operations and more suited to the private sector. It 
considered  the  initial  outlay  very  high  and  the  annual  licensing  and  maintenance  fees 
unsustainable. Due to the proprietary nature of the software, the RAA also foresaw additional 
future costs if regulatory or operational changes required system modifications. This led the 
RAA to ask for additional ADB technical assistance to design a customized audit resource 
management system to optimize its limited resources in the face of its increased responsibilities, 
as recommended by the earlier TA. Given the key role that an audit management information 
system can play in expanding and improving RAA  operations to ensure transparency and 
accountability in Bhutan’s governance, ADB supports this request.

8  The RAA has 10 officers with relevant training and experience in IT. Five of these officers have a bachelor’s degree 
in computer science. Three officers have 2-year diplomas in IT and two have IT training certifications. The IT staff

system.

3 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be improved public financial management in Bhutan. This 
impact will be measured by the reduced amount of unsettled funds in the total account of 
government agencies as a percentage of the approved national budget. 
 
10.  The outcome of the TA will be increased accountability and transparency of public 
accounts. To measure this desired outcome, the TA will look for increased compliance of 
audited agencies with the recommendations of RAA annual audit reports. The TA will also 
monitor the amount of unsettled funds of government agencies that are classified as caused by 
fraud and corruption to determine the achievement of targeted reductions. Finally, the TA will 
also examine the reduction of total field audit time spent by RAA auditors. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  To  achieve  the  intended  impact  and  outcome,  the  TA  will  assist  the  RAA  in 
reengineering its business processes and developing and installing a customized audit resource 
management information system. The TA will automate manual procedures, provide advice for 
improved management of RAA operations, and equip auditors with more powerful tools to 
enhance operational efficiency and effectiveness.  
 
12.  In the first year of the TA, ADB will help conduct business process reengineering, design 
the basic features of the audit resource management information system (ARMIS), and procure 
the necessary scalable hardware and software. In the second year, the TA will help pilot the 
operations of the ARMIS in the head office. Later, the RAA is expected to roll the ARMIS out to 
its regional offices on its own. 
 
13.  The TA will have three major outputs: (i) the reengineered business processes and audit 
procedures of the RAA, (ii) a customized ARMIS designed and installed in the RAA, and (iii) the 
training of RAA auditors and relevant staff in the use of the ARMIS.  
 
14.  The  TA  will  measure  these  outputs  by  (i)  the  acceptance  of  the  RAA  of  the 
recommendations of the consulting firm’s report regarding business process reengineering and 
audit  procedures,  (ii)  the  increase  in  the  number  of  RAA  computers  with  installed  audit 
management software, (iii) the percentage of RAA staff trained in the new ARMIS, and (iv) the 
percentage of audits conducted using the ARMIS. 
 
15.  The RAA will field a dedicated IT team to work full time with the TA consultants to 
conduct a systems review and redesign of RAA audit operational policies and procedures. 
Following approval by the auditor general of streamlined policies and procedures, the RAA IT 
team will be guided by the TA consultants in programming the new ARMIS. The TA will develop 
the  appropriate  specifications  for  the  system’s  hardware  and  software  and,  after  they  are 
procured, install the ARMIS on a pilot basis at the RAA central office for performance and 
security tests. Once a rigorous review and updating of the system is complete, the RAA will 
launch the system for use at its main office. The system will be rolled out to regional offices on a 
phased basis. 
 
16.  In terms of TA impact, the main assumption is that Bhutan’s democratization continues 
to foster strong public interest in greater transparency and accountability in government. The TA

4 
 
also assumes that government support to deepen and mainstream good governance policies 
will continue. The main risk to achieving the intended impact would arise from an external shock 
to the government’s budget situation and a consequent reduction in the priority now accorded 
accountability reforms. 
 
17.  The TA makes two assumptions regarding outcome. The TA assumes that the RAA’s 
use of the ARMIS will enhance the quantity, quality, and credibility of its audit reports. As a 
result,  the  reports  are  expected  to  improve  compliance  and  performance  of  government 
agencies. The TA also assumes that the public accounts committee and the anticorruption 
commission  will  make  positive  use  of  the  RAA  annual  audit  reports  and  respond  to  its 
recommendations, thereby elevating the risk of sanctions for violations and, through deterrence, 
enhancing compliance. The risk to attaining the expected outcome is possible resistance by 
actors in government opposed to accepting and implementing RAA recommendations. 
 
18.  With regard to outputs, the TA assumes that the installation of the ARMIS and the 
training in its application will lead to its effective use by the RAA. The main risk to this output is 
that the designated RAA IT staff members will be unable to do their part due to other RAA 
demands on their time. The RAA has assured ADB that this risk is understood and the auditor 
general has said that regular work of IT staff members assigned to the TA will be suspended for 
its duration. To mitigate these risks, the TA will employ a pilot program prior to full launch of the 
system. 
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $525,000. The government has requested that 
ADB finance $450,000, which will be provided on a grant basis by the Technical Assistance 
Special  Fund  (TASF-IV).  The  government  will  finance  the  balance,  equivalent  to  $75,000, 
through the provision of office facilities, counterpart IT staff time, and various logistical and 
administrative costs. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan is in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The RAA will be both the executing agency and the implementing agency. The RAA will 
chair  a  project  steering  committee  that  will  include  the  public  accounts  committee,  the 
anticorruption  committee,  the  Department  of  Public  Accounts,  and  ADB.  Underscoring  the 
project's priority, the auditor general has appointed the assistant auditor general to be the 
project manager and to serve as the focal point of the project and principal liaison to ADB. The 
RAA will deploy eight IT staff members to the project to work full time, as needed. Five will come 
from the central office (one officer from the IT unit, and four officers from the IT audit section) 
and three from the regional offices. A project director will be chosen from this group to handle 
the project’s daily operations. Three staff members are expected to serve as systems analysts 
while the rest will serve as programmers.  
 
21.  An international consulting firm will be contracted to implement the TA. The firm will be 
selected using the quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost ratio of 80:20. 
Interested firms will be asked to submit simplified technical proposals. The selected firm will field 
a senior systems analyst and programming specialist who will serve as the team leader of the 
project (international, 10 person-months). He or she will lead an in-house RAA IT team to 
analyze, design, program, and install the ARMIS. More specifically, the team leader will (i) 
select and train the RAA IT team that will be responsible for the design and delivery of the 
ARMIS, (ii) conduct a systems analysis of RAA operations and provide RAA with options on

5 
 
how the ARMIS can be designed, (iii) supervise and assist as needed in the programming of the 
ARMIS, (iv) manage the piloting and testing of the ARMIS, (v) design a training curriculum and 
conduct  training for  trainers  in the  use  of  the  ARMIS,  and  (vi)  ensure that the  ARMIS  is 
launched successfully. The team leader will be assisted by a public sector audit specialist 
(international, 1 person-month) in the conduct of a business process review and systems design 
for the RAA. 
 
22.  The team leader will also be assisted by a programming specialist (national, 10 person-
months) who will provide technical support to the RAA team in the programming of the ARMIS. 
The programming specialist will report to the team leader and will also help train the RAA team. 
Before pilot testing the ARMIS, the firm will deploy an IT security specialist (international, 1 
person-month) who will test the integrity of the ARMIS and provide recommendations to improve 
its security features. These consultants will be recruited by ADB in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The detailed terms of 
reference of the consultants are outlined in Appendix 3. Disbursement under the TA will be 
made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). 
 
23.  The RAA will procure the basic hardware (servers, computers, scanners) and software 
for the ARMIS. The procurement will be conducted in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The specific details of the hardware to be 
procured and the estimated cost will be determined during the systems design phase of the TA. 
At the end of the TA, all equipment will be retained by RAA. Residual funds, if any, will be used 
to procure improved database and additional network connections. 
 
24.  The TA is expected to be implemented for 36 months from January 2011 to December 
2013. ADB and the RAA will develop a monitoring and evaluation plan based on the design and 
monitoring framework. Data will be collected and analyzed regularly for the project’s quarterly 
reports. Quarterly ADB missions will be conducted to review the progress of TA implementation. 
A technical assistance project completion report will be produced 1 year after the physical and 
financial closure of the project. 
 
25.  The RAA will disseminate the results of the design and development of the ARMIS at the 
annual  and  regional  meetings  of  INTOSAI  and  the  Asian  Organization  of  Supreme  Audit 
Institutions. The project team will share lessons of the project in the South Asia seminar series 
and in other ADB forums as appropriate. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
26.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bhutan for Strengthening Audit Resource Management, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Systems  analyst  and  programming  specialist/team  leader  (international,  10 
person-months) 
 
1.  The information technology systems analyst and programming specialist holds at least a 
master’s degree in computer science and/or information technology (IT) and/or has achieved 
the requisite certifications in relevant IT fields. She or he has more than 10 years of experience 
in computer system analysis and programming. More specifically, the consultant has significant 
experience in enterprise resource planning systems, preferably in the area of audits. The team 
leader will be fielded by the firm that will be contracted by the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
using ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010 as amended from time to time). The 
main objective of the assignment is to help the Royal Audit Authority (RAA) design and install an 
in-house customized audit resource management system (ARMIS). Specifically, the team leader 
will (i) lead the conduct of system analysis and subsequently recommend a strategic design of 
the ARMIS that does not merely automate existing procedures but reforms them for greater 
effectiveness, (ii) lead the RAA IT team in programming the ARMIS, (iii) supervise the testing 
phase and piloting of the ARMIS, (iv) design training curriculum and conduct training of trainers 
on the use of the system, and (v) conduct user acceptance tests and ensure that the ARMIS is 
improved based on user feedback. 
 
2.  The consultant will do the following tasks: 
 
(i)   System analysis and design of the ARMIS. The consultant will 
 
(a)  analyze  RAA  operations  work  flow  and  identify  areas  of  possible 
automation and restructuring to increase operational efficiency; 
(b)  prepare  system  requirement  specifications  and  a  system  design 
document to be endorsed and signed by the implementing agency;  
(c)  conduct hardware and software needs assessment for the ARMIS and 
subsequently recommend procurement of specific hardware and software; 
(d)  lead the design of the ARMIS and recommend a suitable system and 
development  methodology;  and  ensure  the  ARMIS  is  web-based  and 
capable  of  the  following  functions,  among  others:  (1)  general  audit 
management;  (2)  audit  planning  and  programming;  (3)  resource 
scheduling; (4) risk assessment; (5) automated workflow management; (6) 
resources  sharing  and  field  documentation;  (7)  automated  knowledge 
sharing between audit divisions, teams, and auditors; (8) human resource 
management; (9) asset and inventory management; (10) field monitoring 
and evaluation; (11) quality assurance and control; and (12) any functions 
recommended and agreed to by the RAA; and 
(e)  explore the possibility of broadening the features of the ARMIS to include 
electronic  submission  by  government  agencies  of  their  financial  and 
performance documents to RAA, as well as other electronic features to 
facilitate more efficient resolution of RAA audit recommendations. 
 
(ii)   Development and programming of ARMIS. The consultant will 
 
(a)  identify the various modules of the system;

Appendix 3  11 
 
(b)  draft an action plan to develop the ARMIS, defining the timeline and the 
responsibilities in programming of the team leader, national consultant, 
and the RAA IT team; 
(c)  provide  technical  and  managerial  guidance  on  programming  of  the 
ARMIS to the national consultant and the RAA staff; and 
(d)  train the national consultant and RAA staff, if necessary, in applicable 
programming language. 
 
(iii)   Test and launch the ARMIS on a pilot basis. The consultant will 
 
(a)  draft an implementation plan and methodologies; 
(b)  test  the  ARMIS,  including  application  of  user  acceptance  tests,  and 
improve system deficiencies; 
(c)  finalize programming of the ARMIS and launch it on pilot basis; 
(d)  Conduct a post implementation review of the ARMIS pilot version; 
(e)  develop a training curriculum for 230 auditors on the use of the ARMIS to 
be implemented in close collaboration with the national consultant, the 
RAA IT division, and the human resource division; 
(f)  prepare  user  manuals  and  conduct  training  of  trainer  on  use  of  the 
ARMIS; and 
(g)  draft an action plan to mainstream use of the ARMIS in the RAA to be 
implemented after the end of the ADB project. 
 
3.  The consultant is expected to be easily accessible from both home and onsite locations 
to ensure that his or her inputs are available in the event of managerial and technical issues 
affecting the project. 
 
4.  Deliverables and reports. The following are the consultant’s deliverables:   
 
(i)  Inception report (month 1). It will include diagnostic analysis of all areas under 
the  scope  of  consulting  services  based  on  inputs  by  ADB  and  RAA  staff, 
recommendations on the way forward for each activity, and a detailed time-
bound action plan. 
(ii)  Brief quarterly progress reports. These will summarize the progress achieved for 
each assignment against the agreed work plan, lessons learned during preceding 
quarter, and suggestions for adjustments in the work plan for the next quarter. 
The  team  leader  will  provide  quality  control  on  compilation  of  information 
provided by the national IT consultant and the RAA IT staff. 
(iii)  Other output reports. The following reports will be submitted per ADB guidance: 
(a) recommendations on the design of the ARMIS; (b) recommendations on 
hardware and software procurement; (c) a training curriculum on the ARMIS for 
230 auditors; and (d) an action plan for mainstreaming the ARMIS. 
(iv)  Draft report. No later than 1 month before the completion of assignment, this 
report will discuss findings, achievements, and recommendations. A final version, 
taking into account comments by ADB and the government, will be submitted at 
the close of the project. 
 
5.  Period of performance. The assignment will start in January 2011 and end in December 
2012. It is expected to entail 8 person-months of inputs on an intermittent basis.

12  Appendix 3 
 
B.  Public sector audit specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
6.  The consultant should have a graduate degree in accounting, finance, or related field, 
preferably either a chartered accountant or with a certified public accountant. He or she must at 
least have 10 years of experience working with external and/or internal audit institutions. He or 
she  should  have  knowledge  of  international  accounting  and  auditing  standards  (especially 
public  sector  standards);  experience  in  designing  and  assessing  audit  systems  (business 
process reengineering); experience in conducting audits, assessing auditor competence, and 
following up on issues raised by the audits. He or she must have a strong understanding of 
information systems and the application of new technology. The specialist will be recruited 
through a firm using ADB’s individual consultant system in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010 as amended from time to time). The main objective of the 
assignment is to help the RAA conduct a business process reengineering review of audit 
policies and procedures and internal systems. The specialist will work with the team leader in 
conducting the systems review and systems redesign of the RAA’s audit operations. 
 
7.  The consultant will 
 
(i)  review  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  RAA  policies,  regulations,  and 
procedures using international best practices; 
(ii)  recommend  measures  to  address  gaps  and  weaknesses  in  RAA  policies, 
regulations, and procedures; 
(iii)  assess RAA operations work flow and identify areas of possible automation, in 
consultation with the team leader, to increase operational efficiency; and 
(iv)  conduct other assessments as requested by ADB and the RAA. 
 
8.  Deliverables and reports.  The consultant will submit a draft report no later than 1 week 
before the completion of assignment, discussing findings, achievements, and recommendations. 
A final version, taking into account comments by ADB and the government, will be submitted 1 
week at the conclusion of the field work. 
 
9.  Period of performance. The assignment will start in January 2011 and end in June 2011. 
It is expected to entail 1 person-month of inputs on an intermittent basis. 
  
C.  Information technology security specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
10.  This specialist is a holder of a master’s degree in computer science and/or IT. She or he 
has more than 8 years of experience in computer system security analysis. More specifically, 
the  consultant  has  been  involved  in  the  security  testing  of  a  web-based  management 
information system, preferably in a government agency with high security requirements. The 
consultant  will  be  recruited  through  a  firm  using  ADB’s  individual  consultant  system  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010 as amended from time to 
time). The objective of the assignment is (i) to test the integrity and security of the ARMIS during 
its pilot phase and (ii) provide recommendations to improve the ARMIS security features.  
 
11.  The RAA will provide the consultant with a written permission to conduct the security test 
of the ARMIS before the assignment. The consultant will  
 
(i)  conduct integrity and security tests of the pilot version of the ARMIS, 
(ii) identify threats to and vulnerabilities in the system, and 
(iii) provide recommendations to improve the system’s security.

Appendix 3  13 
 
 
12.  Deliverables and reports. The consultant will submit a system security report, including 
recommendations for the improvements of security features of the ARMIS, on the last day of the 
assignment. 
 
13.   Period of performance. The assignment is expected to start in January 2012 and end in 
June 2012. It is expected to entail 1 person-month of inputs on an intermittent basis.  
 
D.  Programming specialist (national, 10 person-months) 
14.  The programming specialist is a holder of a master’s degree in computer science and/or 
IT. She or he has more than 8 years of experience in computer programming and is well versed 
in most programming languages. More specifically, the specialist has been involved in the 
programming of an integrated management information system or enterprise resource planning 
system, preferably in the area of audit. The main objective of the assignment is to help the RAA 
to develop an in-house ARMIS. More specifically, the consultant will help the team leader and 
the RAA IT staff in programming the ARMIS. 
15.  Tasks. The consultant will  
 
(i)  support the team leader in conducting the system analysis of the RAA’s audit 
operations and identify areas for reform and automation to increase operational 
efficiency; 
(ii)  support the team leader in conducting hardware and software needs assessment 
for  the ARMIS;  
(iii)  contribute to programming for the ARMIS, as guided by the team leader; 
(iv)  provide technical guidance to the RAA IT staff; 
(v)  train RAA staff, if necessary, in applicable programming language; 
(vi)  help the team leader test the ARMIS and improve system deficiencies;  
(vii)  help the team leader finalize the programming of the ARMIS and launch it on a 
pilot basis; 
(viii)  participate in training of auditors in the ARMIS in collaboration with RAA staff; and 
(ix)  assist the team leader in drafting an action plan to mainstream the ARMIS in the 
RAA, for implementation after the TA ends. 
 
16.  Deliverables and reports. The consultant will report to the team leader and provide 
inputs as requested to produce various reporting outputs. The consultant will work with the RAA 
IT staff in programming the ARMIS.  
 
17.  Period of performance. The assignment will begin in January 2011 and end in December 
2012. It is expected to entail 8 person-months of inputs on an intermittent basis.
